So uh what exactly is the validation
framework right?
So uh I define it as a framework in
Unreal that alerts people about what's
wrong and uh it does give some uh
features to you know fix it up. I'll get
into that in a bit, but it's mostly
about alerting people about what's wrong
and what do you do to uh enable
validation. So, uh first of all, we have
the data validation plugin. Uh and as
you can see, it has um a lot of
dependencies in Unreal. So, it's always

default. Um but there is this little

called asset referencing restrictions.
Uh if you guys attended Jack Condan's

As far as context go, meaning like when
can you trigger validation? I've broadly
classified that into two. Uh it's manual
and automatic. So what do you consider
manual? Right? So any asset in the
content browser you can right click on
it and it has an option to validate. You
can also validate assets plus
dependencies the option right below that
you can uh validate all assets from a
folder. So you can rightclick a folder
and you can say just validate. You can
also validate all assets across the
project. Um a little note over there uh
if if it's a project like a thousand
assets uh you might be fine but uh at
the scale we are at uh we find that it
mostly uh you know either runs out of
memory and crashes the editor. So we do
not recommend it if uh it's a large
project at least from my side. Uh and
then we have uh validating uh from the
command line. uh you can just use the uh
uh Unreal editor command.exe for that.
Coming to the automatic context, we have
onsave which means that every time you
save an asset, uh it triggers a
validation and also on presummit meaning
uh you open the um uh view changes
window and you try to submit an asset,
it will always fire uh whatever you set
up validation for it. At Lightseed, we
find that it is better to focus on the
automatic context uh because it's more
consistent. Uh people always save,
people always submit, but you can't
really, you know, base your pipeline on
people promising that they will do it
themselves. Um I mean it works uh to a
degree, but uh in a pinch it's always
good to rely on automatic context.
So where do we start at LSLA? Right?
This is the first question we asked like
why why do we want validation right? Um
and uh the context here is that uh we
did not enable validation from the

but uh we were uh considering like um uh
at that point this was in 2023
uh how we could improve our workflow and
what we could do to enhance our pipeline
and validation came up. So we found that
uh we needed to repair um there were a

now if we implement it at this point

that you know again earlier is better

and we knew that once we get into that
paradigm the file count is just going to
explode. everything is connected. Uh
everything depends on each other and
it'll be really hard to uh get to the
actual issue if we didn't have
validation.
So this was our tech stack at that
point. Uh we were at 5.3. Uh we used uh
PFOS for uh source control and uh along
with that came the swarm um system uh
for code review and uh we were doing our

So uh specific to uh you know how we
wanted to implement it, we reached out
to various teams and we uh you know
asked them like what do we want? what is
important validation right and um they
came up with a a few things. So we
already had many common warnings and
errors coming up all the time and uh
they said yeah we really want to fix it
and then uh investigating further we
also found that certain asset types were
throwing more errors than uh not
um there were also specific studio
workflows that uh you know we're always
running into issues and they were like
please help us we need validation. uh so
and then uh you know certain team
requests um uh which I'll get into in a
bit. So based on all that we decided on
the following. So we decided that we
would upgrade some warnings to errors
because uh at that point uh we had a lot
of warnings uh that were causing issues
down the line whether it be stale
references they were just sitting there
and then uh you know someone would check
in based on that stale reference and
then would break another asset. So uh we
thought that okay if we have uh upgrades
to errors that'll be more noticeable.
We also started with static meshes. They
were the biggest culprits because uh
when we investigated like what are the
major asset types throwing these issues
it was static meshes.
Also uh if we wanted to validate we also
needed to uh have uh the principle on
what is valid right so we wanted to
define standards beforehand and then say
like okay team here are the standard
assets this is what we expect otherwise
like at that point many teams were like
oh yeah we'll just define our own
standards and uh you know we hope that
other people adopt it but then everybody
had competing standards so that wouldn't
just work. Um we also decided like uh
early on we knew that we would be
upgrading engine versions and uh there
were uh lot of usage of uh engine assets
at that point and um in one of the
upgrades uh we found that like one asset
was in a particular location it was
moved and that was causing a lot of
issues. So we said okay we're not going
to go with engine assets. Uh wherever
possible it's not possible all the way
uh but wherever possible we would uh
rely on our own assets. So if we wanted
to use something that was in the engine,
we would like uh import it into the
project and use that.
And also we wanted the team to
experiment of course uh it's a game and
we were doing a lot of experimentation.
Uh so we decided that developer assets
there's a specific content folder called
developers and we decided like you can
do whatever you want in there. It will
never get into the game. So we don't
care. So that was uh you know uh kind of
relieving to many people because they
were like if everything is validated how
do I do this crazy thing that's not
supported? Uh so uh that was uh also
decided
and then um uh okay so now I'm going to
go through a little bit of the code. Uh
so to upgrade warnings to errors we
defined our own uh custom macro in a
central location like build.h
and then we went to a site of a common
issue in this case uh uh if people have
been using validation this might be
familiar it's a failtoload package which
is a very common issue with uh stale
references. We went there and we did two
things. We used our macro to um put it
as a map check error so that when uh the
uh the level loads uh you would get the
error and also we made sure that uh when
it's an error we would u switch the
context to the uh message log so that
they actually see oh there are there are
errors coming up otherwise like we found
that people were just oh it's an error
it's sitting in the background they
wouldn't see it or uh it it might be
easily ignored. So uh with this we found
that hey why is this error coming up and
people were messaging all over the place
and then you know people could jump in
and fix the issue.
So uh as recommended by Epic we also um
you know overrode the base uh editor
validator class and uh this is an
example of the static mesh validator. So
the important uh function is the
validate loaded asset implementation.
You could put all your validation logic
in there. Uh everything else um uh you
know uh decides when the validator is
fired. So with this class in place uh
this is what it looks like in the
editor. So we would like uh make a
blueprint an editor utility blueprint
out of that class and it would be an
asset and then the asset would have uh
the knobs and dials we needed. So for
example in here u we have the ignored
paths which means u you know as I said
the static meshes were in a bad state.
So uh we wanted a facility to ignore
certain paths until they were fixed
otherwise like people would start uh
doing some new assets and then old
errors would come in and then uh there
would be issues. So we had that facility
uh in place in the validator
and uh as mentioned uh we had standard
assets and uh the most common standard
asset is uh the basic shapes. So when
people wanted to you know um block out
something they would go here and these
were originally like uh engine assets.
So we overrode all that and uh made sure
that uh for example the cylinder CMZ is

underscore we have uh prefix uh
validation and uh we have our own uh
material uh and all this was done uh
with this code. So uh we would have a
custom uh level module with a specific
delegate that we would override so that
when you load the editor it actually
loads our assets not the engine assets.
Similarly we also had standard levels.
So uh here you can see empty open world
which was like completely blank and a
basic open world which had some static
meshes and lights. Uh both of these were
world partition which is important
because by default like if you do a new
level it comes in as non world partition
and since we decided that uh everything
would be uh involved partition we want
to enforce that
and uh that was pretty simple not much
changes required on the code side just
uh go to project settings and put in
your levels and that took care of that.
We also enforced uh standard asset
names. Uh this is what that looks like.
We had specific requests from our
animation team, art team saying like uh
we want uh you know for example uh
materials to come in with a specific
naming convention so that we can like
search for it after the fact and
identify it because outside the editor
uh you can't identify any U asset. Uh so
that's what this is. Uh this is a data
asset that has a mapping between uh
classes and the prefixes. And um for
example, if you uh like I mentioned, if
you uh added a new material, it would
automatically pull in from here. So the
material m and it would say m material
instead of like I think um yeah, Unreal
says new material.
uh which is not what we wanted. So uh
this is what that looks like. So uh we
would um override with again with our
custom macro uh saying like hey don't go
to your engine uh default look at our uh
standard data asset pull in the mapping
from there and then uh you know uh we
have the new name.
Uh similarly uh this is a special case
but uh it was important because uh a lot
of designers were using uh the modeling
mode. Uh it's it's great it's amazing
but uh the assets that come from it they
don't have any standards. So uh we had
to enforce it there as well. As you can

they would come in as like um you know

So with all of that implemented um you
know what were the results?
Well yeah everything went great. uh all
errors were fixed, everybody was dancing
and uh thank you for of course not there
were challenges there were a lot of
challenges and uh I just go through some
of them uh it's not extensive but these
were things that started coming up again
and again
so for one um because like I mentioned
um there were a lot of people coming
from wellestablished studios they were
more familiar with uh the perfos client
than what we had in the editor. And
although they look visually very
similar, there were some fundamental
differences. For example,
we have uh a revert option in the
editor. So when you revert it, uh Unreal
is good about reverting that status from
the PFO server as well as uh locally
from disk. But if you do the same thing
from the PFOS client unless you uh check
that little box which is uh disabled by
default uh the PFOS status gets reverted
but the uh file remains on disk and then
PFOS doesn't know that the file is there
and this caused a lot of issues because
now uh you had stale files just sitting
there and they had active references but
uh PFOS didn't know about it and uh when
it came to Unreal, it didn't even know
what to do with such files.
Uh yeah, talking about PFOS, anytime we
had any kind of connection issues, uh
there were adverse effects, uh for one,
like all the files that were out of date
would go to something called the
uncontrolled change list. And uh in many
cases, the most egregious cases like uh
stale files that sat in here for like 2
months, 3 months without people knowing
that they were out of date and then they
would go to check in those files and
they were already stale. So they would
already have uh you know reference
issues.
And then uh there was also the option uh
for a force delete which means like uh
if you had uh active references you
could still ignore them and say force
delete. And that way uh all the stale
references were left behind. And then
some uh operation like uh redirector fix
up which we did frequently uh would not
even know what to do with these tail
references because the original uh path
was already long gone.
And then uh you know uh the uh in
general like uh the content teams uh
found it really confusing as to what the
error messages meant. So for example
like we would get things like oh this is
missing from this change list but I did
not touch that file. Why do I want to
include this in this change list? And
then they would call us over and uh we
had to like figure out oh there is this
thing that is down the chain that you
had to include but you did not. Uh
similarly like you know invalid world
assets what does that really mean? There
was no context. Uh it was just like
here's the error good luck. Uh so uh
there was lot of that kind of ambiguity
that existed
and this was a big one because um
uh the validator system mostly looks at
assets and um if you have specific
issues with actors it doesn't catch that
well. Uh in this example, we had uh
already an issue with the asset that you
know was spamming the log. Someone would
fix it on an actor saying like, "Oh
yeah, okay, I fixed this issue, but it's
still throwing the error." Why? Because
it's an issue on the asset, not on the
actor. And if there was a second actor
with the same issue, it would still
throw the same uh error. So this got
confusing
in the reverse case. uh if there was um
you know no issues with the asset but
then the actors uh had like an for
example in this case it had an invalid
uh nanite non-compliant material uh it
would still say oh yeah there's nothing
wrong nothing to see here because uh the
asset itself was valid
and uh yeah we ran into this issue as
well as as I mentioned uh we were trying
to not uh use engine assets. Uh but um
when you deleted assets uh Unreal would
be nice and uh replace uh the deleted
material with world grid material if
there was nothing available and that was
an engine asset. We found that a lot of
things just got auto applied and uh we
didn't have any way at that point uh of
dealing with it.
So yeah uh uh some UX issues uh
obviously like there were long
dependency chains for container assets
like level instances which had other
assets within it. Uh if we tried to
validate it, it would just take way too
long or run out of memory.
Uh yeah, the legacy assets were uh
causing friction because people would
edit uh things that were dependent and
not know why this asset is throwing an
issue.
uh if there were exclusive checkouts.
This is kind of um uh you know PFO
specific uh issue uh where if you had an

uh asset redirector fixup uh what was
checked out would not be changed but uh
it would allow that redirector to go
through anyway. And then later on
because there were stale references that
would cause issues.
Uh we didn't have uh any integration on

what was wrong with the asset because

So yeah with all these issues what we do
uh where do we focus our efforts? So for
one, we uh decided like uh this was
important enough to dedicate some time.
Uh we made sure like whatever uh UI um
uh the PFOS client had uh we we would
try to mimic it to a certain degree. So
for example, this this is uh a custom um
uh size and we put in uh the uh change
list number right on the title bar. And
uh as you had many errors uh it you
could scroll through them all within the
window versus like um in Unreal by
default you have to go back to uh the
message log. And that was really uh
cumbersome.
Uh also we enhanced a little bit of the
view changes window where all the change
lists are um uh shown. So we had like a
sort uh button and then like we
shortcircuited the default uh change
list to like create a new change list uh
and conform to our standards. Uh and
also we enhanced the uh notification
system to like uh have a little more
context uh when errors were thrown. That
original message was just like failed.
That's it. So uh yeah uh these are some
specific things that we did on submit.
As I mentioned like a lot of stale files
were sitting uh in uncontrolled changes.
This is what we did. Uh on every submit
uh we uh took all the files and we
converted them to the default change
list. So that way there were a lot of
incidents of like hey why are like 3,000
files suddenly coming into our default
change list. Now we know
because it was uh stale uh change list.
And uh this is uh this came up a lot
when we implemented it because as I
mentioned there were people sitting with
stale files for a while and also we uh
this was a request from our content team
as well. Uh they said like I have fixed
my issues but when I check the error log
there are still those errors. Um why is
that? Have I solved the issue? I don't
know. So we found it uh more helpful to
like clear the message log when uh you
validate it. So we would clear the asset
check and the source control part
portion and that way like they knew for
sure like when you sub uh tried to
submit you would get the latest errors.
So this is a big one. Uh revert from the
editor did not work uh all the way. So
it it was mostly uh when uh you loaded
an asset into memory and it was staying
in memory uh and then you try to do
something with it. Uh and this was a
constant issue uh and what people would
do is like ah I don't like this let me
go to perfose and uh revert and then you
would encounter that same issue where
when you reverted and like you did not
check that check box you would again get
into a stale stage. So we made sure to
unload the packages uh uh that were in
memory when you uh reverted and that
seemed to work well. Uh people are now
reverting all the way. It's very rare
that people revert outside uh the
editor.
So we al this is an example of uh when
uh there were new files uh that uh were
uh people were trying to delete it with
active references. So we put in custom
code so that uh if there are active
references that would be flagged and say
hey this is a list of all the assets
that you need to you know uh either
delete or make sure that there are no
references before you can delete this
one asset. Uh and that also worked well.
Uh many times we ran into issues with
external actors because we had to go
back to Perforce and find it manually.
But at least it was taken care of before
submit and did not come into the package
and cause issues. This is actually when
we detected uh uh the issues on the
actor itself. So when we detected that
the it was the external actor, we would
actually um uh take that and load it as
as a file object and that was usually
enough to make sure that the uh issues
specific to the actor came through. And
uh we also found that putting a limit on
the uh actual dependency uh or the
iteration count was very helpful. So uh
you know you had one thing that you
changed in the uh level instance and uh
it had a deep reference chain it would
only take in a maximum uh iteration
count so that only what you changed was
uh actually validated instead of like uh
I have to wait like half an hour just to
validate this single material change. So
that's what we did uh with like
including an iteration count and this
made it possible to actually iterate on
uh container or aggregate assets.
Uh this is what I mentioned before the
asset restrictions uh plugin. Uh in this
specific case, we had a workflow that we
had with our outsourcing partners where
they would include files that were not
vetted and we had to make sure that
these files did not get into the game.
This was very hard because uh the uh the
outsourcing assets had the same name as

would when they were looking for the

added like a rule saying like hey
anything in that outsourcing folder is
restricted the moment they validated uh
it would come up saying like hey uh this
is not allowed for submission. And this
would like also throw up many other
issues that already existed saying like
hey you submitted this asset this has an
outsourcing issue. So we could clean up

Very helpful.
And I'm going to give uh three examples
of more specialized uh validators or
validations on our project. For one, I
don't know how familiar people are with
this uh but we had a lot of material
instances with
uh excessive amounts of material layers
and uh this was getting too egregious
and uh more material layers means more
permutations means performance hits. So
uh we worked with Techart to decide on a
you know sane account and uh we said
okay uh you want to submit anything over
our limit. Nope. You're going to go
through this validation and the moment
we detect any kind of layer count uh
that's above that uh no you got to fix
it.
Another special case is uh when we had
uh scene capture components in
blueprints uh and um they came in with
uh capture every frame and capture on
movement every frame. Uh this was a
heavy performance hit as you can see and
uh uh we made sure in our blueprint
validator that anything that came in
that way uh we would flag and we would
tell them to fix and u if you needed to
use such components then you could
enable it on runtime.
Another case is when uh animation
montages uh came in with animation
sequences out of sync. uh we had a
button to fix it uh but no one noticed
it uh and it just went through

saying like hey you have these things

button before you submit. Um and that

uh as mentioned like uh aggregate assets

Uh and yeah uh similar point uh it got

Cook breakers were constant. This was

Otherwise we had issues where um there's

So what do we learn from all these?
Invest early in validation. As you would
have imagined like all these issues uh
might have been a little uh less
egregious if we had invested right from
the beginning where we were in a clean
state and not only that we actually
